reviewText: You don't quite feel for the characters the way the intensity forces you to feel in Liam Neeson's "Taken." Much of the intensity of the subject of human trafficking is gone because we are constantly shown the victims, but perhaps this is the effect the makers intended. It's really a dark world, but it could have been darker with more appropriate lighting and acting and music.
summary: Discusses a very important contemporary subject, but tackles it in a relatively boring fashion.

reviewText: First, to correct some of the Spotlight reviews: the Polish girl was NOT a tourist.  She was lured in Poland into signing up with a company that promised to sneak her illegally into the United States via Mexico.  She paid them, and when she got to Mexico, found herself a captive and her child back in Poland under threat unless she complied.Second, I didn't find it incredible that a guard at a detainee camp should have shrugged off the Polish girl's claim.  He must hear such claims a dozen times a day.  Not that I'm defending him.  He should have reported it.This problem is important, and that it is made possible by the government's present Open Borders policy is one of the things people should become incensed about.  Close the borders, the trade is no longer profitable, the trade dries up.  Alternatively, leave the borders open and play police and try to trace every single one of the thousands of women and children being trafficked across every night.  Which approach is more likely to succeed?See alsoAshanti, andHuman Trafficking.My most serious complaint is that in "Human Trafficking", the bad guy is an American.  In "Trade", the bad guys are the Russians.  Fine.  I'm sure there are Americans and Russians involved in this trade.  But are we to believe that the Islamists have abandoned this form of commerce after engaging in it for thousands of years?  And the Mexicans?  They're also not interested?  It would be nice if Hollywood could come up with some villains other than Americans and Russians.

reviewText: This is sadly a very real movie.  It's the reality we live here in my country and within the U.S. of course.  The execution is brilliant, the script is well written, the performances of the actors and actresses are all great.  I think every parent should watch this movie with their children and educate them about the reality of the situation.  It'd be very advisable for every school to do the same thing with the students.  The reality of our world has dramatically changed and we as parents and teachers have to educate our children with that perspective in mind.  Since we cannot be with them on a 24/7 basis, this movie is a great tool to show them how the predators are, think and act.  The best protection we can give to our children, is to teach them the awful truth and the dangers of the world they live in, and how to protect themselves from all that.  It's not about becoming paranoic, is about becoming aware.
summary: Tragic, Sad and Very, Very Real

reviewText: My Mother and I have lived in Mexico City and the U.S. which are the places where this movie takes place.  So we were immeadiately intrigued when we came across this film while flipping through the tv channels one evening.  What we experienced via this movie is the engrossing, yet horrifying realization that this sex trafficking evil is permeating the underworld of both of our homelands.  It is a well done film, showing how the Russian mob is trafficking girls to Mexico from Eastern Europe and then smuggling them (and some local Mexicans as well) across the U. S. border for bidding into the sex trade.  The movie opens with a girl receiving a bicycle from her brother as a birthday present.  An innocent enough gift from our sheltered U. S. points of view, but an alarming gift from the Mexican Mother's point of view who forbids her daughter from ever riding it. Eventually, the girl goes looking for her brother on her bicycle and the cause for her Mother's concern becomes clear. As the thirteen year old girl is kidnapped off her bicycle by the Russian mob and sold into the sex trade.  Her brother tries to rescue her and is aided by an American cop looking for his daughter, who was sold into the trade ten years prior.  One of the powerful moments in the movie is the alive but inwardly dead blonde girl after she is brutally raped by her kidnappers.  In closing, this is an engrossing movie about a topic that is willfully being ignored by our society.  It is an eye opener.  And will stir one's inner psyche in a heart wrenching manner.  This is the power of motion pictures.

reviewText: I was in Mexico for the first time over 20 years ago. While driving a Jeep we came upon a man with a rifle and a gate that read "detour". As we drove over the mountain road we were assaulted and robbed at gunpoint. That is the Mexican mentality. Why work for money when you can just rob someone who has. Needless to say I have never been back. I was given this movie and was disturbed beyond belief at how inhumane we can be to each other when sex and money are involved. I LOVE horror films with special effects..they are fun! The real horror of this film or should I say terror...is that it is REAL and happening every minute of every day. It is called supply and demand. If there was no demand these little children would not be raped, sodomized and brutally beaten for the "kicks" of perverts. The sad thing is...those perverts are our husbands, boyfriends, teachers, law enforcement..the very people who are supposed to protect us. The reason is because most men are animals who will stop at nothing to satisfy that "urge". Be it little children, non consenual sex ( Rape ) even sheep aren't safe from most men. There are a few of us like myself who are decent men and only sleep with each other as long as we are consenting adults. This movie made me sick to my stomach but it is a must see for all those "Peppermint Patty" housewives in the suburbs who live in Stepford Wives World.  Where was YOUR husband last weekend? A little Business trip to Mexico or was it Thailand?

reviewText: Based on an article written by Peter Landesman, who also wrote the story and co-wrote the screenplay with Jose Rivera ('The Motorcycle Diaries'), TRADE literally forces us to experience the cruel, vicious international market for sex slaves.  It is brutally captured on film by director Marco Kreuzpaintner ('Summer Storm') in a manner that spares nothing to unveil the atrocities created by the many people form all countries who ply this trade.  It is a tough film to watch, but it is also an important film to see: the public MUST be made aware of this criminal activity that robs the lives of children and adults around the globe.The setting is Mexico City and in the poor sector lives a fatherless family supported by the oldest son Jorge (Cesar Ramos) whose 'occupation' is petty crime that allows him to bring in money for his mother and his beloved sister Adriana (Paulina Gaitan).  We see the abduction of a beautiful young Polish girl Weronica (Alicja Bachleda-Curus) in the Russian sector of the city.  Soon after Adriana, trying out her newest bicycle gift from Jorge, is likewise abducted.  The girls (and boys) are kept in filthy apartments awaiting border crossings into the US where they will be shipped to New Jersey for sale after being advertised for auction on the Internet. Jorge discovers the absence of his sister, traces her to the Russian sector where he sees the filth in which the victims are kept, but where he also encounters a Texas policeman Ray Sheridan (Kevin Kline) who is continuing his years long search for his daughter.  The two 'meet' and join in the chase for the lost girls.  And it is the manner in which Jorge and Ray gradually become friends and the clever way in which they cooperate that forms the rest of the story.Yes, the film is overlong and borders a bit too closely on soap opera techniques, but the acting is so committed and the story is news so important that any flaw in the film can be forgiven because it opens the door to a crime that is all too unfamiliar to most citizens.  It is a true story  and therein lies the terror. It should be seen.  Grady Harp, January 08
summary: The Dirty Little Secret of International Sex Slave Trade: A Wake-up Call
Title: N/A

reviewText: International sex slavery seems to be a fact, not a myth. The internet has certainly contributed by making it easier and spreading it wider across the globe.  From Thailand and Poland to Mexico and then to the US are the stations of the supply chain in this grim story. That is globalization, as one of the kogs in the chain says. The kogs are global themselves: Russian, Mexican, American, the Maledives even play some part.This trade does not lend itself as a subject for entertainment. As an action film, this one, Trade, is not better than mediocre. I would feel bad if I were to criticize it for its imperfections. But there seem to be some problems in the time line, which is hardly realistic; just to mention one weakness.As a semi-documentary its essentials might withstand scrutiny, I don't know. Giving it the benefit of doubt works, because one is exposed to similar stories in 'real life' all the time. Again assuming that the press does still serve a purpose in providing information and not just sensations.
summary: Doing justice to this subject is hard

reviewText: As we are told at the end of the movie, in the US alone, an estimated 50,000-100,000 children and adults are sold into sex slavery (now euphemistically referred to simply as "trafficking") each year (over 1 million internationally), and the US agencies charged with fighting the slave trade do not try to rescue victims.TRADE tells the poignant and riveting story of a teenage boy's search for his kidnapped sister. It relates what I am told are some of the real-life horrors of the sex trade. While some aspects of the tale are nearly wrapped for Hollywood packaging, the film's message comes through loudly and clearly.One aspect of the sex trade that was ignored, presumably to avoid upsetting users of pornography, is that many victims of trafficking end up as fodder for the porn industry. Thus, porn users contribute to the problem.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Trade is a film everyone should see. Unfortunately, the Internet has made it easier for sleazeballs to market young Mexican girls to perverts.There's really not much to say about the acting in this film. Kevin Kline's performance was lean and economical--his role wasn't overwritten, which helped to keep the focus on the film's sad premise.The film's plot revolves around a young streetsmart Mexican punk and his younger--13 year old--sister. Russian slave-traders abduct the 13 year old girl and process her and others out of Mexico and into the U.S. Meanwhile, the girl's older brother persuades an American tourist--insurance man--to help him find his little sister. It's here that the movie threatens to lose focus by staging political--and cliche--verbal exchanges between Kline and the Mexican punk. Thankfully, though, these exhanges were brief and interrupted by scenes involving the trafficked women and their sadistic keepers. Like livestock, the women are packed and shipped in trucks, held in  dungeons, and shepherded across hot acrid terrain. Prospective buyers molest the stolen women who are dazed and numbed by all the drugs their keepers feed them.As a film, Trade doesn't break any new ground; however, the film's subject is potent enough that there's no need to do anything to distract from its main focus.

Title: N/A

reviewText: I liked this movie. Not because of the inherent qualities of it as a movie but because of the message it was trying to convey.Judging from some of the reviews out there some people are trying to make more out of implied politics than it genuinely contained.The fact of the matter is that there are slaves in the world and some of them live in our world, whether we like it or not. Some of the best selling non-fiction works of the last few years have been about the trafficking of people across borders. Every once in a while a story surfaces about people who abuse slaves in their homes IN AMERICA, people who are often good citizens.The dramatisation in this story does leave something to be derired but it is a very human tale of people who care in a commodity based world where the lives and existance of some people count for nothing. Indeed some of the reviews reflect that viewpoint.In my view Trade does nothing more than open a chink in a blind. To get public attention on a worthwhile cause is difficult enough in a corporate media world and sometimes anything that can get a worthwhile message across to even a few people is worthwhile doing anyway.Trade sends out an emotional message. Ask any mother how she would feel and act if her child was stolen and some understanding will be gained. If that message requires some additional drama to help than perhaps that is a good thing.There is no such thing as a perfect movie, otherwise none of us would have anything to write about. I would encourage everyone who reads and writes on such pages as these to encourage as many people as possible to watch this movie and then to ask your local opinion formers what they are doing to end the scourge of slavery. And anyway, how many of us are aware of the slaves in our towns and cities? Are we so sure that such things could never happen where we live?
summary: Money, it's a hit. Dont give me that do goody good b...

reviewText: This is not a fun movie, and given the subject matter, it shouldn't be. Sex slavery has received increasing attention lately, but most people here still associate it with Thailand or Russia. This film drives home the fact that it could be going on not too far from where you live. And as the film demonstrates, it's very difficult to do anything about it.This isn't great movie-making. It becomes pretty predictable in places. Several times, it's contrived and relies on improbable coincidences to keep the pursuers on the track of the bad guys. And the final confrontation in New Jersey ends disappointingly formulaic and flat.  But the acting by largely unknown actors is solid, and having all mostly use their respective native language (with subtitles where necessary) adds a touch of authenticity. Even Kevin Kline, whom I could never stand as a comedian, does a credible job; for most of the film he seems somewhat befuddled and lost, which actually fits perfectly with his character. There are a few flashes of brilliance in the film: The field of reeds is one of the eeriest sequences I've seen in a long time. Do such places exist? Knowing what we do about the state of humankind, why shouldn't they? And at the very end, the film seems to satisfy your appetite for revenge, and then a few seconds later with a very simple device makes you stop and question it. Superbly done.

reviewText: This film was not critically praised (27 on Rotten Tomatoes), but despitea melodramatic second half, the film was informative, disturbing, andfor me, riveting.  Like "Pay It Forward", Kevin Kline again stars in a movie with a serious social message.  A 13 year old girl is kidnapped bya ring of sex-traffickers, who sneak her and a few others, out of Mexicointo America and other countries, to be sold to pedophiles, often forvery large sums of money over the internet.  Since the movie is meant tobe educational as well as entertaining, some realism is sacrificed.  Butit is intense and riveting, and the performances are good.  While it wasmade by the maker of "The Motorcycle Diaries" which was considered a farbetter film, having seen both, I would rather watch this over againdespite its rather obvious flaws.

reviewText: Trade takes a much ignored topic, the global sex trade, and gives it attention, in a movie that doesn't seem to know what direction it is going in.The plot itself is pretty basic, two different women from two different countries are obtained for the global sex trade, one by kidnap and one by deception.  The thieving brother of the young kidnapped girl goes on a quest to track and find his sister.Enter Kevin Kline who is on a quest of his own, he find the brother hiding in his car and for his own reasons believes his story and adopts his quest as his own, a quest that takes them thousands of miles across country.Many of the characters are cliches, particularly the villains, the filmmakers take advantage of the seriousness of the topic to hide some scenes so badly done that if the movie was about any other you would simply groan.Nevertheless there are some good performances here.  Kevin Kline continues to show that it doesn't matter if he is a cowboySilveradoa crazy idiotA Fish Called Wandaor given horrible materialThe Pink Panther (Special Edition)he can act.  He takes his character and makes him both interesting and a valve for some subtle comic relief.This is one point where the filmmakers made a good move, this movie presses on you so hard that it is very necessary to have some relief, Kline's underplayed comic relief works here to give the viewer a chance to breathe.It is worth noting that both Caesar Ramos and Alicja Bachleda do very well with what they are given.One other oddity.  The movie seems to end at three different points and I was fooled at each one of them before we got to the actual ending. Threw me off quite a bit.You really get the impression the producers wanted the audience, (particularly the DVD audience) to think that the act of seeing the movie was in fact "doing something" about the issue as if it wanted to pretend it was a documentary rather than a movie. That seemed to cheapen it.All in all I think the topic deserved a better movie but this one will have to do, I wouldn't pay to own it but it makes it as a DVD rental.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "Trade" provides a good introduction to the sort of horrendous underground economies that have boomed with the expansion of neoliberal economics.  One thing that is missing from accounts of the sex trade is an analysis of its root causes.  There has always been prostitution and sexual exploitation, but never on the scale that it is on today.  For that sort of deeper understanding, I'd suggestRogue Economics: Capitalism's New Reality.Ideologues often celebrate so-called "free trade" and events like the fall of the Berlin wall, but we rarely take a look at what these developments have meant.  Since the collapse of the Soviet Union, life expectancy in Russia has dropped by ten years, and prostitution and smuggling have flourished in what has become a mafia state.  Journalists who criticize the crony capitalism and its failures often end up dead. Similar economic catastrophes have unfolded in Latin America and throughout the Global South, where wealthy men travel to rent the bodies of poor people.  There are even books such asThe Hedonist: World Sex Guide - Single Male Erotic Vacations in Rio, Costa Rica, Thailand, Carribean and much morethat advise men on where to go to purchase women.It's all quite depressing.One problem I had with this film is how it ends with police swooping in to save the day, like the calvary.  No doubt, police can have an important role to play in bringing people to justice.  Yet, police and other agents of the growing global police state are often very much involved in sexual exploitation themselves.  Guards at prisons, members of our military, DEA/DHS/ICE personnel, and border guards often demand sex from people who are detained or whose countries we've invaded.Against Our Will: Men, Women, and RapeU.S. generated media is also among some of the most sexist material ever created, adding to the devaluation of women as simply sex objects.Rape on Prime Time: Television, Masculinity, and Sexual Violence (Feminist Cultural Studies, the Media, and Political Culture)Maybe future films on the sex trade will cover economic roots of this injustice, as well as portray women's groups and social justice groups that are working on these issues.  It won't be state security forces that save the day, but rather a larger movement for social justice.Worlds of Women: The Making of an International Women's MovementThe Fourth World WarSome resources to learn about women's issues and how we can contribute to making the world a better place to be female:MsTeen VoicesNew Moon: the Magazine for Girls & Their DreamsWomankind: Faces of Change Around the World
Title: N/A

reviewText: I dont intend any offense here but I went into this film based on what other members wrote about it expected something very grim and horrible. I was led to believe from what I read that this was going to an extremely dark, sick, violent film. Im actually glad that it wasnt like that at all. Though the subject matter of this film is very grim, its one of the least dark or violent films I have seen on this subject matter or similar subject matter. I suppose the movie gets the point across but it does so without being graphic at all. There is very little violence in this film and one very mild and brief rape scene. Everything else is simply suggested along with one or two girls getting slapped around very mildly. The reason however I felt compelled to give this film only 3 stars is that it simply doesnt seem belivable on any level. What I mean by that is that the script, production, and director attempt to make this realistic and frank, but all attempts fail miserably unfortunately. I have seen a lot of films labled as disturbing or grim and this one is the least disturbing, dark, or violent I think I have ever seen. If your looking for something shocking or genuinly upsettling or disturbing then your going to be truly dissapointed. See the French shocker Irreversable or the film based on Jack Ketchums book The girl next door and youll see what I mean. And in fact if this movie shocks or really disturbs you I highly urge you to forget about either film I just mentioned. This movie tells the truth, but it tells it very weakly and doesnt begin to illustrate just how bad this subject is in reality. This is a watered down tale with no sense of what things are really like. Maybe thats a good thing, because what really happens is far darker than anything this film tries to get you to believe. Still this is a pretty sad story.
summary: Not nearly as disturbing or shocking as some have claimed, still a fairly good movie..
Title: N/A

reviewText: When most people think about illegal immigration, they think of South American people crossing borders in order to assume low level jobs such as: migrant workers picking fruits and vegetables, house cleaning positions, kitchen work in the restaurants.  But what many people seem to ignore or simple are not aware of is the fact that women and children are the most vulnerable beings in this process.  The get traded as sex slaves all over the world.  Without documents, language skills and awareness of how to contact authorities for help, their destinies are bleak.  This film tackles some of those topics, but it leaves more questions unanswered.  Film is an eye opener, but I must say one does not hear much about this talked about in public.  In some respect, this topic is still very much a taboo.
summary: Another side of illegal human trafficking

reviewText: The Demise of Sarah Mae: Murder in the SwampUntil yesterday, I'd never heard of the movie "Trade" with Kevin Kline. My son said his wife's friend told them it was an outstanding movie, so they rented it. Both my son and daughter-in-law said they cried when they saw it. They loaned it to me and I watched it last night.Wow! The moive is rough, I kid you not. But it is full of painful realities that most of us do not want to face. This is a story of children and young adults being kidnapped and sold in a world market  - human trafficking!It is a must see, if you can handle it. Although it is certainly not for the weak of stomach. And I must say, I cried, too, not only at the end but in several other places.This is one of the best, in-depth stories I've seen in a long time, and I fail to understand why it is not better-known. Or, maybe we all had our heads in sand dunes someplace. It is one great story, though. Certainly one that should get plenty of notice!

reviewText: I saw this at the Passion '07 Conference in Atlanta, GA at a special advanced screening, and I have to say that it is one of the most powerful and important films that I have seen in a long while. It portrays the horrors of sex trafficking, and how it affects the victims. The story is of a young man whose young sister is kidnapped and sold into sex trafficking. He teams up with a cop, played by Kevin Kline in a really good performance, and they set off to find her.There are times when it resorts to cliches, and there are times when the dialogue is less than perfect, but I believe that these are only minor problems, and they did not dilute the film's strong message. I believe that the filmmaker's set out to show us something which is extremely important, something that should be dealt with. I hope that people see this film, and are able to look past the minor criticisms in order to see the bigger picture.This is a tragic story, but most importantly it is a story of hope and redemption, and the little ways in which God looks after all of us.Rated R for graphic depictions of rape and some language. I wouldn't recommend this for anyone under the age of 17.

reviewText: Since I live directly across the Rio Grande from Juarez, Mexico, movies that involve this locale are of particular interest. Other reviewers have provided detailed plot summaries, and I concur with their generally favorable opinion of the overall production; however, a few flaws detracted from my enjoyment.First, the young brother appears to follow his kidnapped sister from Mexico City to Ciudad Juarez in a "borrowed" beat-up old 70's car. The trip appears to take an hour or so and is accomplished on less than a tank of gas. The boy has no money and could not buy food or gasoline if he needed it. Anyone even remotely familiar with Mexican geography knows that the distance of this little "jaunt" is well over 1000 miles, and would require several days and $300-$400 worth of gasoline. I guarantee that the author of this screenplay knows this and simply chose to overlook it because it does not serve the plot. While many Americans are naive with regard to international geography, I feel that this conspicuous oversight was lazy, needless, and troubling. When obvious liberties are taken with minor points, it can make one question the veracity of other, major ones. This movie is presented as being based on fact; therefore, it should be more careful with the "facts" it presents.Second, while the girls are in custody of the Border Patrol in El Paso, TX the Polish girl attempts to inform the B.P. agent that she and her friend have been kidnapped. The agent brushes off her allegation with a "yeah...sure". In light of currently high concerns for national security, the presence of a Polish national in custody for illegally crossing the Southern U.S. border would be a matter of great concern and interest. Her accent alone, without allegations, would draw close scrutiny and interrogation. The callous presentation of the B.P. agent is overdone, unrealistic in this circumstance, and more likely an indication of personal animosity on the part of the screenwriter. Again, it may serve the plot, but it is neither fair nor realistic. Border Patrol agents perform an immensely difficult, dangerous, and generally underappreciated service to this country. They deserve better treatment by the media.Finally, I have lived in this area all my life, hiking and off-roading extensively, and have yet to hear of truckloads of young, kidnapped foreign women "servicing" disgusting perverts in cane fields. It may be going on every day, and in the movie appears to be going on in my immediate vicinity, but I have yet to see any evidence or even hear rumors of it happening. The scenes in the movie are quite disturbing, however, and serve the plot well, but are they accurate? In addition, the area in question is subject to intense aeriel and ground scrutiny by federal agents, night and day, making the activities depicted quite likely to be detected and thus, unlikely.In conclusion, the movie is indeed harrowing, entertaining, and worth the price of rental and (perhaps) purchase. The violence associated with the drug trade is currently tearing Mexico apart. The movie, Traffic, provides a realistic representation. Currently, there are heavily armed soldiers on the streets of Juarez, attempting to maintain order and reduce the escalating levels of violence and murder. This movie makes it appear that other, more subtle and yet equally disturbing crimes are being perpetrated against women in this area and on an international scale. If movies such as this, however flawed, draw attention to legitimate atrocities, then they should be seen, but greater attention to accuracy and detail would make the movie's theme more compelling and its basis on fact more convincing.
Title: N/A

reviewText: As I sit down to write this review for TRADE, there's a late night commercial for the "Girls Gone Wild" DVDs.  Weird.  You can feel outrage for the foreign victims of an evil sex trade while watching drunken young American girls carrying on like total sleazes for free booze.  Nice world.When it comes to movies that deal with the shadowy international sex trade, Hollywood only knows two speeds: a totally depressing pseudo-documentary that'll completely bum you out or some late night CineMax exploitation movie with someone like Shannon Tweed or another softcore B-movie queen in some mild bondage.  You either get lots of harsh reality or lots of sleazy nudity.Well, TRADE is the former.  Just letting you know which one you're getting.  If you want a titillating but grungy B-movie mostly set in border strip clubs and ends with a big ridiculous shootout...go somewhere else.  And get a life.TRADE begins in the depressingly real squalor of Mexico City.  A single Polish mother is brought to Mexico for a "trip to L.A. and stardom" where she's immediately beaten and raped by the Russian mob.  The Russians also nab a 13-year-old Mexican girl while her street smart brother, an up and coming earner who victimizes tourists looking for sex with kids in a totally unrelated enterprise, begins an improbable rescue mission that goes from Mexico to New Jersey.  (Sounds preposterous, but it works).  The brother joins up with Kevin Kline, a former detective searching for a long-lost daughter of his own.The first part of the movie is raw and depressing.  It has a stark realism, believable characters and excellent acting.  The middle is a road picture as the girls are driven across the US to be sold while Kevin Kline and the brother bond on a parallel course.  The last part is the most "movie" part: everything converges in a choreographed ending that ties up everything.But this is one of those movies--like the old HARDCORE movie of the 70s with George C. Scott or the sexless "8MM" completely populated with sleazy men and an overacting Nicolas Cage--where the subject matter blunts the impact of the movie.  The medium pales next to the horrific reality of the sex trade.  Almost every man is a disgusting pervert or a vile gangster pimp, the women are virginal victims totally defiled and desecrated by them...okay, we get it.  Life is horrible.  It's really, really horrible for some people.I don't want the sleazy exploitation movies (they're even simpler) but I would like to see a movie sometime where the black hats and the one (maybe) white hat aren't so broadly painted.This is a well-made but sad film and any real victory in the end is weighed down by all the girls and women still out there who will not get a happy ending from real life.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Although the film was well done I felt that this movie was made more for entertainment than to make a statement or reveal an existing condition that must be stopped. The story was too fabricated and unrealistic and therefore bypassed the reality of the real horror. Human Trafficking with Mira Srorvino was a better film describing the truth of the ugly topic.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The sexual trafficking of women and children around the world is one of the most deplorable crimes and also one of the least understood and under the radar. Having watched a mini-series called Human Trafficking starring Mira Sorvino and Donald Sutherland, I was eager to check this movie out.It is a riveting story and well-told. The story centers around the abduction of a Polish tourist, and also a 13 year old girl in mexico City[Paulina Gaitan] and how her 17 year old brother[Jorge Cesar Ramos] goes all out to find her. He is joined in his efforts by a Texas investigator, played by Kevin Kline, who has also been searching for his own missing daughter [for years]. Turns out the kidnapped victims are being transported to New Jersey where they are to be auctioned off online.This is a very disturbing movie and very graphic. The scenes of abuse and rape are unsettling to say the least. But, it is a story that needs to be told, and the public need to be made aware that these atrocities are happening, often under the noses of the authorities and people who seem to turn a blind eye to these monstrous acts.There are so many commercial movies that the paying public goes to see, and that's fine. Yet, movies like these that have a powerful social message seem to be grossly underrated and underappreciated. "Trade" may not the definitive movie on the subject, yet it is definitely one with a powerful message that hopefully serves to educate the general public about the horrors of sexual trafficking.
summary: A grim movie about human sexual trafficking
Title: N/A
